title:
meeting melissa

ten years ago i had a date with a woman named melissa. there's a much longer story ...

attachments.displayName:
meeting melissa

ten years ago i had a date with a woman named melissa. there's a much longer story behind it, but it ended strangely and negatively. it caught me so off guard that i felt as if my internal gyroscope had been smacked out of its stabilizing role. i was wondering what we return to, what's our center, when things get completely out of whack. not trusting mind/memory, and knowing that all of the cells/atoms in our body turn over across time, i was trying to figure out what our anchor is. my only real answer was the breath. in any case, the day after the date, i was in my drawing class (i was only a few weeks into taking art classes for the first time since 6th grade, over 20 years) and we had a composition exercise that day. i was struggling to know what to make, and out of the fogginess that i was experiencing, this piece emerged. it's titled "meeting melissa."

i was thinking about this piece again due to a comment by +Justin Jenkins on my most recent sculpture (http://goo.gl/WEU6HE). i was noticing some similarities.

and way out from left field i feel like navigating to the core of either of these pieces through all the whirling shifting walls is like beating the mcp cone in the old tron arcade game. how's that for random geek trivia associations?!

more minutiae: i had a date this spring, almost exactly ten years to the day of the one mentioned above, with another melissa. that one didn't go well either.

and finally, the two large black lines in the middle-left of the composition are the chinese character for "human." as i was fooling around with the elements during composition, i didn't have that in mind, but once i plopped them down, i said, yes, this belongs here. being human.

object.content:
meeting melissa

ten years ago i had a date with a woman named melissa. there's a much longer story behind it, but it ended strangely and negatively. it caught me so off guard that i felt as if my internal gyroscope had been smacked out of its stabilizing role. i was wondering what we return to, what's our center, when things get completely out of whack. not trusting mind/memory, and knowing that all of the cells/atoms in our body turn over across time, i was trying to figure out what our anchor is. my only real answer was the breath. in any case, the day after the date, i was in my drawing class (i was only a few weeks into taking art classes for the first time since 6th grade, over 20 years) and we had a composition exercise that day. i was struggling to know what to make, and out of the fogginess that i was experiencing, this piece emerged. it's titled "meeting melissa." 

i was thinking about this piece again due to a comment by +Justin Jenkins on my most recent sculpture (http://goo.gl/WEU6HE). i was noticing some similarities.

and way out from left field i feel like navigating to the core of either of these pieces through all the whirling shifting walls is like beating the mcp cone in the old tron arcade game. how's that for random geek trivia associations?!

more minutiae: i had a date this spring, almost exactly ten years to the day of the one mentioned above, with another melissa. that one didn't go well either. 

and finally, the two large black lines in the middle-left of the composition are the chinese character for "human." as i was fooling around with the elements during composition, i didn't have that in mind, but once i plopped them down, i said, yes, this belongs here. being human.

and on my birthday last year, my camera found another similar image in a sculpture at cornerstone gardens:
http://goo.gl/jP2geJ

Our anchor is faith, and faith is universally connected to a higher power which in turn is symbolized by space and time outside our world. Here you show a wonderful arrangement that reminds me of a organized galaxy and objects being whirled inward towards the center, which is the anchor.

thanks justin. yeah, the helical whorl appears now and then in my pieces.

as far as the faith thing goes--still trying to sort that one. ;)

and back to the composition. it's cool to hear your alternate interpretation. i always viewed it as this ever-shifting thing, with no stable center and no concrete boundaries.

Spirals are definitely a wonderful shape! They call to mind creativity and chaos. Within chaos stability can be found but the best stability is movement. As far as the Melissa name and bad dates.... it might be a karma thing. Sometimes we repeat a situation until we learn what we need to know.
Ufff we should plug all names into that thingamajig before we go on any more dates +james kalin ;)
+Lala M. Haha.Good one Lala.

my only real answer was the breath...  
that is so beautiful..  i'm going to have to think about that and let it sink in for a while..  brb..
Life called, you answered. Life called but again, you  answered. You gave us this, we answered. You replied, I AM HUMAN. A circle was completed and so it begins again.
thank you for all the great comments everyone.

title: Google+ List of Comments for an Activity
